story:
Summary

My name is Topper Sundquist. A couple years back, I IndieGogo'd funds to illustrate and publish a book co-written with my daughters, titled 'Princess Ninja'.  It was the story of a young girl who was born a little... different, than the rest of her family. The final result was more awesome than I could have imagined, and I couldn't have done it without the help and support of friends and family.

WHELP... I'm at it again. 

'Powered By Candy' is a story about two siblings, tasked with the nearly insurmountable task of most awesome breadth and peril: clean their bedroom. Realizing that this was, indeed, a fate worse than death, they turned their vast intellects to the most obvious solution, namely a robot that will clean their bedroom FOR them. 

Unfortunately, due to poor planning, their robot was designed to be powered by candy, which they can't afford until they get their allowance. 

 

 

The Artist

Helping me out this time is young, wonderful UK illustrator, Bethany Evelyn (https://www.bethanyevelynart.co.uk/).  The art is already flowing, as you can see from this very page! Even better, my youngest daughter, Ophelia, produced a complete set of original concept art which we showcased at Fancon, which Bethany has used as the basis for all 48 bright, colorful pages!

 

The Impact

Every donation great and small will help cover art, publishing, marketing, and the like. Donators of $20 CAD and up will get their very own copy in the mail, signed by the authors!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page! Tell your friends! Drink 8 glasses of water per day! Pet a cat!

story:
Story of My Book

Young Adult Life: Navigating the Best and Worst Years contains stories from everyday people navigating young adult life and mental health. This book was made to be your friend in times of loneliness and in times of growth.

My name is Colleen Finney, and I am the author of Young Adult Life: Navigating the Best and Worst Years. I wrote this book because, throughout my own mental health journey, I read many self-help books that made me feel like what I was going through wasn’t acceptable or okay. They made me feel like an alien and often gave me a three-step guide to changing my life. It never worked and made me feel worse. 

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover that there are many people your age dealing with similar struggles. In this book, I hope to instill in you the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for navigating the highs and lows of life as well as the stigma behind mental health. Ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you not feel alone in the worst times and to use the advice given from everyday people in the best times. 

In this book, you'll learn about many mental health topics and how people worked through them, as well as the struggles people deal with every day and the advice they give to get to the other side of the tunnel. You'll hear stories about:

Being in relationships and going through breakups as a young adult.

Breaking down your childhood trauma and seeing how it sets the foundation for the rest of your life. 

How depression can consume you and what it can teach you in the long run.

You will love this book if you have dealt with the highs and lows of life, struggles throughout your own mental health journey, or just need to feel like you’re not alone. 

Young Adult Life: Navigating the Best and Worst Years is a nonfiction book that speaks to young adults and people juggling mental health who want to look at mental health topics surrounding people, moments, and internal struggles in a new way.

 

The Book — Young Adult Life: Navigating the Best and Worst Years

The book is written in three parts.

Part 1 (People) contains the introduction and chapters Family Isn’t Everything, Relationships: the good, the bad, & the ugly, and Friends: they come and go. This section covers the outside source of mental health that you can’t control: other people. This section includes stories of being in relationships and going through breakups, as well as weird family dynamics and the trauma they can cause. 

Part 2 (Moments) contains chapters Childhood Trauma: the foundation of it all, The Best and Worst Years of Your Life, and “That will never happen to me.” This section covers the moments in your life that have a lasting impact on your past, present, and future. This section includes stories about how childhood trauma affects the rest of your life and my own story with being sexually assaulted. 

Part 3 (Internal Struggles) contains chapters Normalizing Depression, The Power of Support with Depression, The Fear of the Unknown: exciting, but oh so scary, Accepting Living with the Impossible, Therapy and Seeking Help, and the Conclusion. This section covers the biggest part of mental health: the mental part. It includes everything that affects you internally and the world around you. This section includes stories from others about their struggles with depression and anxiety, as well as the ups and downs of living with an illness or diagnosis. 

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December of 2021.

The Cover Design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)

The Layout Design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).

The Copyediting for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.

The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this winter. 

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish and a handwritten thank-you note.

Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”).

You will receive early access to the Introduction and some excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback.

You will have the opportunity to be involved in selecting my cover and title.

You will be invited to join my Author Community and get behind-the-scenes sneak peeks into the publishing process.

And much more!

Campaign Goals

Tier 1: Hit $5,500 and the ebook/softcover editions get published (this is the minimum needed)
Tier 2: Hit $6,500 and the book will get a hardcover edition
Tier 3: Hit $8,500 and we’ll get an audiobook edition.

 

About the Author

Colleen Finney is an aspiring broadcast journalist who just recently graduated from the University of Kentucky and is on the hunt for her first “big girl” job!

During her time at UK, she published many blogs about her struggles with depression and mental health, and the feedback she received was alarming! She knew then that someday she wanted to write a book that was the friend her blog post had been for others. She is also very passionate about mental health and wants to help change the stigma behind it. She thinks it’s time we start talking about our feelings and struggles because they are the things that make us human. 

Outside of this book, she is your average, everyday young adult trying to figure out life, just like the rest of you. She still goes to therapy and is very much still trying to figure out what makes her feel alive and what drags her down. She loves spending time with her friends and family and making memories any way she can. 

For more information, you can connect with Colleen at cefinney99@gmail.com and on social media!

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/_colllleeeen_/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/colleen.finney.3/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/_colllleeeen_
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/colleen-finney/

story:
The book and audiobook "Los Hilos Que Tejen, en el Corazón del Hombre Inmigrante " shows the vulnerable voices of 22 men from seven different countries living in the United States.

"Los Hilos Que Tejen, en el Corazón del Hombre Inmigrante ", which will be published in Spanish, provides a unique space to celebrate the courage, fear and vulnerability of men to be able to express themselves and generously tell us the most intimate side of his challenges and strengths to get ahead in this country.

The message is one of perseverance, love, solidarity, power, especially the power to succeed despite the barriers. They have turned barriers into bridges, leading them to paths of discovery and empowerment and to a process of being heroes of their own lives, while giving positive examples to their family and their communities.

Your support can shed light on these voices of men of different roots, beliefs and lifestyles that show us the other side of the immigrant man, the hard-working, powerful, tenacious, determined, creative, persistent man, but at the same time full of tenderness and nobility in his heart.

 

 

El libro y audio libro “Los Hilos Que Tejen en el Corazón del Hombre Inmigrante” nos muestra la vulnerable voz de 22 hombresde siete diferentes paísesque ahora residen enlos Estados Unidos.

“Los Hilos Que Tejen en el Corazón del HombreInmigrante,” publicado en español, provee un espacio único para celebrar la valentía y la vulnerabilidad del hombre de poder expresarse. Ellos generosamente compartensus desafíos, temoresy fortalezas para salir adelante en este país.

El mensaje es de perseverancia, amor, solidaridad, poder, valentia, y especialmente el poder de salir adelante a pesar de muchasbarreras. Ellos han convertido las barreras en puentes, llevándolos a caminos de descubrimiento y empoderamiento y a un proceso de ser héroes de sus propias vidas, mientras dan ejemplos positivos a su familia y a sus comunidades.

Buscamos su apoyo paradar luz a estas voces de diferentes raíces, creencias, y nacionalidades que nos muestran la otra cara del hombre inmigrante: El hombre trabajador, poderoso, tenaz, determinado, creativo, persistente, pero al mismo tiempo lleno de ternura y nobleza en su corazón.

story:
I'm Jessica Bebenek, a Montreal-based poet & transdisciplinary artist. This spring I was selected to participate in the Banff Centre for Arts & Creativity's residency, the Writer's Studio, a five week program which allowed me to dedicate time to working on my poetry manuscript, No One Knows Us There (now nearly completed!) Unfortunately, I was not allotted the government funding which I'd been assured was certain and would cover the full cost of attending, and I'm now $4000 in debt from the experience. Yikes!

What We Need & What You Get

I'm asking for your help to be able to recoup a portion for this debt: if you've ever thought of purchasing a poetry book, a custom notebook, knitted poetry, all-natural skincare, or workshop services from me, I would be deeply grateful if you chose now as the time!

The Impact

Recouping some of this debt through my creative work will allow me to spend less time pursuing childcare labour, etc. and more time working on my creative career & poetry manuscript, for which I'm aiming to have a first draft ready to send to publishers before the end of the year.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share with anyone you think may be interested. Thank you so much for your support!

story:
My name is Kerry Clifford. I live in Windsor, Vermont. In August 2016, I learned that I have terminal stage-4 colon cancer.

One of my first responses to that earth-shattering news was to write about it. And for the last few years, through my blog called Cancered Plans, I've invited many of you along on my journey through this, shall we say, unexpected turn of events. I've tried with humor and brutal honesty – and hopefully a few insights as well – to make real an experience that is both uniquely my own and relatable to many. I hope my words can teach each one of us how to endure.

As I recently shared with you all, my journey is coming to a close. I began hospice care last month, and one of my great and final wishes is to bring the first year of Cancered Plans into book form.

It's a body of work I'm deeply proud of, and I hope that by publishing this book, my story remains a source of hope for anyone whose best-laid plans get "cancered," and a reminder that with the love and grace of community – dogs included – you can find the strength and courage to fight.
 


What We Need & What You Get

I am raising funds to be able to publish and print 100 copies of Cancered Plans. I'm striving to reach this goal as soon as possible, without knowing how much time I have left, so I can hold the book in my hands – and so you can hold a copy, too.

You may choose simply to contribute at any generous amount – and have my undying gratitude.

You may also choose to claim a "Perk" (in honor of my favorite coffee shop, Boston Dreams):

  • Choose "Single Espresso" at $25 and receive 1 copy of Cancered Plans
  • Choose "Double Espresso" at $50 and receive 2 copies of Cancered Plans


Meeting the $2,500 goal guarantees 100 copies of the book get made. If we more than meet the goal, and if Perk requests exceed 100 – well, then we'll print more books. That just means you all are more awesome than I could've imagined. 

 

How Else You Can Help

Of course I understand that not everyone is able to contribute, but you can definitely help in other ways.

  • Help me spread the word about this campaign on your favorite social media channels.
  • Or drop the link for this campaign page into an email and send it to folks in your life who might like to help – and who might resonate with my story.


Thank you for your abiding love and support. Above all, thank you for making this dream come true.

story:
I'm in love with Kimono, its rules, its shape, its sumptuous textiles, its rise and fall. 

A brief video: http://voice.adobe.com/v/E4Jrt6YXkuu

My fascination with kimono began 13 years ago when I lived in a small town on the Island of Shikoku and worked as an English teacher with the JET Programme. In the southern part of Ehime Prefecture, where I lived many people still wore kimono everyday. I didn't really know that much about kimono back then, I just knew it was something special  - unlike any garment I had ever seen before.

It affected me so much that I pursued a masters degree research project on Japanese retailers selling kimono online, improved my Japanese speaking abilities. From 2009 - 2012 conducted interviews with people in the present day Kimono Industry in Kyoto, Japan.

I've lived in Ehime, Osaka, Kyoto, Tokyo, and Sapporo (for almost 5 years combined), and talked with more than 300 people who have worn and still wear kimono for special occasions and daily life. During my time in Japan and as an academic I've become an expert on all things kimono.

Recently, many of the people who I met and were working in the industry are leaving, moving into new industries and they have contacted me with the opportunity to tell their 'real' story now that they have left the kimono companies. Its clear that Kimono is dying slowing but surely...and I need to document the story of the people who are trying to keep it alive before its too late.

I've worked with Kimono industry leaders, and producers who will help me complete this project. I've written a portion of the book already.

The Book Contents so far:

Chapters: I. Japanese Kimono is Dying II. Yuki's Kimono III. Resuscitation (followup with Kyoto City officials) IV. Nao's Kimono V. Okumura's Kimono Shop (one more interview) VI. Kyoto Kimono Station - the last heartbeat VII. Kimono is Dead

With the people I have met previously, and this new invitation, the story of kimono can be preserved. I need help getting back to Kyoto as soon as possible for several weeks. I intend to go in late February 2014, and only require airfare and daily living expenses. There I will meet my contacts and record their stories then return home to complete my book.

My Budget:  I'm asking for the minimum amount possible from you:

$1100, that's my air ticket from Honolulu to Osaka. 

$400, for my meals and train travel to Kyoto.

I'm sleeping on the floor at a friends house to save $!

My project timeline looks like this:

September 2014  (2 weeks if funded) - arrive in Kyoto and reconnect with my contacts interview with Kyoto city, Kimono wholesalers association, 3 employees of a kimono makers shop.

October 2014 - return and write up chapters 3, 5, 6, 7.

November 2014 finish and revise chapters 1 and 7.

December 2014 - self publish my book, and write to publishers who may wish to pick up.

I thank you for any and all help you may be able to provide.

record their stories then return home to complete my book.My Budget:  I'm asking for the minimum amount possible from you:$1100, that's my air ticket from Honolulu to Osaka. $400, for my meals and train travel to Kyoto.I'm sleeping on the floor at a friends house to save $!My project timeline looks like this:  September
 2014  (2 weeks if funded) - arrive in Kyoto and reconnect with my 
contacts interview with Kyoto city, Kimono wholesalers association, 3 
employees of a kimono makers shop.                                      
                October 2014 - return and write up chapters 3, 5, 6, 7.November 2014 finish and revise chapters 1 and 7.December 2014 - self publish my book, and write to publishers who may wish to pick up. I thank you for any and all help you may be able to provide.

story:
Help Us Fund Our Inaugural Prizes for Writers of Color!

My name is Tyler Tsay, and I am the Editor in Chief of The Blueshift Journal (theblueshiftjournal.com), a tri-annual, international literary magazine dedicated to creating and exploring that which binds us together. Started in the summer of 2014 by Lily Rockefeller (executive editor), Claire Carroll (creative director), and myself, Blueshift has been a true labor of love, with fifty staff members working tirelessly around the globe and thousands of individual submissions received each issue. We've been honored to publish a wide range of artists, from budding high schoolers to accomplished career writers. Each season, your wonderfully positive feedback has inspired us to keep running as long as possible. 

Unfortunately, over time, we've noticed that payment for writers is scarce these days, especially within marginalized communities. We believe great writers should get the reward they deserve, so for the first time ever, we are excited to present our first ever The Blueshift Journal Prizes for Writers of Color! Check out our website with a whole bunch more information: theblueshiftjournal.com/brutal-nation.

Meet the Judges

JESS X CHEN (POETRY) is a filmmaker, multi-disciplinary artist/activist and nationally-touring poet.  Her work exposes narratives of colonial trauma, diasporic love and collective protest by connecting the violences between the queer and colored body and the body of the Earth. A graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, her work has appeared in Asian American International Film Festival, The Huffington Post, The UN Human Rights Council, and at the Asian Cinevision Diversity Screening at the New York Times. Her poetry has appeared in Nepantla: A Journal For Queer Poets of Color, Hyphen, The Margins and is forthcoming in The Offing. She is a recipient of the 14th Armed With a Camera Fellowship for emerging Asian-American filmmakers. Through art, organizing and education, she is working toward a future where migrant and indigenous youth of color see themselves in stories, whole and heroic, on the big screen & then grow up to direct their own.

JEFFREY RENARD ALLEN (PROSE) is a Professor of Creative Writing at the University of Virginia. Allen is the author of five books, most recently the novel Song of the Shank (Graywolf Press, 2104), which is loosely based on the life of Blind Tom, a nineteenth century African American piano virtuoso and composer who was the first African American to perform at The White House. The novel was featured as the front-page review of both The New York Times Book Review and The San Francisco Chronicle ; it won the CLMP’s Firecracker Award; it was a finalist for the PEN/Faulkner Award, and has been nominated for the Dublin Literary Prize. Allen is the author of two other works of fiction, the novel Rails Under My Back, which won The Chicago Tribune's Heartland Prize for Fiction, and the short story collection Holding Pattern, which won The Ernest J. Gaines Award for Literary Excellence. Allen has received other accolades for his work, including a Guggenheim Fellowship and Whiting Writers' Award. His website is www.jefferyrenardallen.com.

What We Need

It's simple.  We calculate that we would need about $1000 to float the whole campaign with free submissions.  On our end, we can cover about $250, but with Submittable and website payments accumulating each year at about $1000/yr already, it's tough for us to handle more than that without breaking the bank.  If we're able to reach our target goal of $750, we can easily run the Blueshift Prizes with absolutely NO CHARGE for submitters.  We want every writer to be able to submit, regardless of their financial situation.  But we need YOUR HELP to get there!  Any amount of donation helps, whether it's $1 or the whole $750 (please, oh please).

What You Get

$5: Addition to the Blueshift Prizes' sponsors list and a personalized thank you email from EIC Tyler Tsay.

$10: Handwritten thank you letter and addition to the Blueshift Prizes' sponsors list.

$20: Blueshift Tote bag (plus everything above)!  Grab them while they're hot, newly designed just for you :)

$35: Access to the secret, never-before released pdf of Issue 4, featuring rad-design by rad-designer Lily Grossbard (plus everything above).

$50: A luxurious print edition of Stories of the Invisible and Brutal Nation combined, only available through donation (plus everything above).

$100+: Free Feedback Corner submissions and print editions ad infinitum!  Also potato salad, three staff members' souls (your pick), pieces of the rainbow, and everything mentioned above.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make some noise!  Find us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/TheBlueshiftJournal/?f...) or Twitter (@The_Blueshift) and share/like/comment/wow about The Blueshift Prizes to everyone!  With every share, about 500 more people see our posts, if Facebook analytics are anything to be trusted - we'd greatly appreciate the online support, even if you aren't able to contribute.
  • Also, you can share the Indiegogo page straight from this website!

story:
Here is the first chapter,
translated by Virginia McClain!

---

 

Gabriel could barely keep running, but stopping wasn’t an option. The Shadows that followed him were too close. He didn’t need to look back to know that.

He had never seen a Shadow before, but after the too long minutes of hiding from them he knew them well enough. They wouldn’t stop until they got him.

Snow covered his brown hair, and his coat couldn’t protect him. It was so cold that his throat hurt with each breath. But he could tell that if one of the Shadows reached him he would feel something far more chilling than the air that surrounded him.

The stone walkway over which he ran offered him a clear path to follow. He couldn’t remember how he had gotten there, but that didn’t matter to him anymore. The only thing left to do was run. Escape. Not let the Shadows touch him.

It was a very dark night, but a hoary light allowed him to see a few meters in front of him. He couldn’t be sure but it seemed as if the light became brighter and brighter as he ran. As though he were getting closer to its origin.

How much longer would he have to run to reach it?

It was then that he felt it. Something had grabbed his ankles. Something colder than the snow he walked on. Gabriel tripped and fell flat on his face.

The Shadows surrounded him and he could no longer see the light that he had been following. A darkness even darker than the night enveloped him. He couldn’t see anything, he couldn’t even breathe. He knew he was about to die.

He was only fifteen.

Someone began to sing then. A feminine voice, sweet but firm. He couldn’t decipher the words, but he understood what they spoke of: the light that he was supposed to reach.

The song sought him out, getting closer and closer to the place where he had fallen. The Shadows withdrew then, as though they had been dispelled by the music, and he could once more see the light.

Clenching his teeth, numb, and full of terror at the thought of being touched by the Shadows once more, he ran. He ran with the kind of speed that men use to evade death.

The song grew fainter and fainter, but the light shined brightly on. When he was only a few meters from it, he no longer felt the Shadows behind him.

What he saw, however, was not a light, but rather a giant bird, whiter than snow, more radiant than the stars.

With a smile, Gabriel approached one of its wings and caressed it.

If he had thought he was going to die when the Shadows reached him, contact with the bird was incomparably more painful. He felt that his heart was going to explode, that his body burned while his mind tried to reunite the ashes of what it had once been.

 

Gabriel awoke suddenly with his breath faltering and his body stuck to sheets soaked with sweat.

It had been years since he had called for his mother when he had a nightmare. This time would be no different. He drank water from the glass left on his nightstand each night, and tried not to close his eyes. He knew that if he did he would once more see the Shadows.

What he couldn’t even imagine was that, in that same moment, something else had awoken.

story:
LUX uses technology to re-imagine the relationship between written and spoken word, visual art, and the traditionally bound journal.

LUX was created in 2013. It was the brainchild of the combined efforts of Sarah Lawrence alumni Nicole Cloutier, Christina Harrington, and Carolyn Silveria. And it was an instant hit. This multimedia oriented creation takes the concept of a literary journal and spins it on its head. The end result? QR codes and poetry; photography and short stories; fiction and film; and, we hope, a continued interplay of other mediums.  

(Learn more about Lux) 

This year, as we put together LUX Volume II, we want to take the word ‘multimedia’ to a new level. We seek to build upon the strong foundation begun last year by expanding the journal’s print quality, visual arts technology, and spread of artistic content.

Last year, while we still managed to create a beautiful, letterbound journal with a simple, eye-catching cover, we are ready to take the printing to a new level. We’d like to change the physical dimensions of the book, transforming its chapbook-like shape into a less traditionally bound medium. This year, we also want to incorporate more visually engaging art--since last year LUX was limited to printing only two full-color pieces. 

(Click here for a multimedia experience ) 


GOALS 

This year, we seek to deepen the connections between color and literary expression. We want the journal’s visual elements to be as rich as its written and spoken ones.  We also want to deepen LUX’s breadth of content; last year we had fiction, poetry, and one moving film, and this year, we’d like include storytelling through the form of podcasts, songs, both written and instrumental, along with a greater number of film submissions.

(Listen to MEMBRANE) 


Help Us Bring LUX to A Greater Audience

In order to make these expansions and build upon the artistic intent of the project, we’ll need to raise at least $3,000 to account for both higher quality print materials and the necessary marketing budget for spreading awareness of LUX and increasing its annual submissions, as well as to compensate both new and established artists for their contributions to the journal.  The more resources we have available to further our vision of LUX as a rare hybrid of interactive media, the more we can share it with a greater audience and create a rich array of work by artists of all mediums. 


We strive to connect with the world simultaneously through the beauty of the printed page and by engaging with the limitless space of technology. 

The success of LUX largely depends on how effectively we will be able to cull and collaborate with a range of artists across the media spectrum.  With greater funding and resources, the production schedule of the journal is destined to be more labor intensive than it was for prior publications.  We face the challenge of coordinating and synchronizing the vastly varied visions of the painters, photographers, writers, filmmakers, and podcasters chosen for each publication.  As such, our layout planning and execution using technology will also be more involved.  Despite these potential obstacles, however, we know our staff will rise to the challenge and maximize opportunities made available by greater funding and wider community support.

THANK YOU FOR ALL YOUR SUPPORT !!!

story:
Approximately 2.7 million children under the age of 18 have a parent in state or federal prison according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, and the number keeps growing. These children have a higher risk for drugs and alcohol abuse, antisocial behavior, dropping out of school or declining in schoolwork, as well as aggression, disruptive behaviors, and depression when compared to other children. These factors make it more likely that the children will enter the prison system when they are adults. Kaia and the Birthday Kites author, Larry Bratt, is an inmate at Jessup and sees these statistics become reality all too often. This book is positioned to give hope to the children of the nation's incarcerated, and to encourage them to follow a different path than their incarcerated parents. We also hope that this book can start a dialogue within our nation, and throughout the world, about these often hidden victims of incarceration. 

THE STORY:

Kaia is about to turn 13. 

Her birthday is on March 25th.  So is her dad's. Like any young girl about to celebrate a big day, she wants to celebrate it with the one she loves most. Only one problem. She'll have to get past the guards.  And the watchtower.  And the electric fence.  And the angry dogs tethered to leather straps.  Because Kaia wants to deliver dad a present, the perfect gift for dad and daughter to share. And the ultimate symbol of freedom: two kites. On father and daughter's birthday, Kaia wants to fly those kites with dad...in the prison yard.

[Read excerpts HERE.]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

HOW CAN I HELP?

Author Larry Bratt has turned around his life and, in the main, has turned around the lives of many others inside and outside the walls of Jessup.  That's why we're asking you to help us get him published. We want to spread Larry's (and Kaia's) message of perseverance and why it's important to do what's right even if your life didn't start out that way.

We need your help by donating funds and spreading the word about this book. Larry needs your help, too.  After covering production costs, Larry intends to take his portion of sales revenue from 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites' and reinvest in the young and the old. Larry will commit a portion of his proceeds to the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland's 'Camp Amazing Grace' for the children of incarcerated dads and moms so that they can attend summer camp. He will also invest his proceeds into the Prison Hospice program to bring comfort to and improve palliative care for inmates who are terminally ill. Your donation will continue to give long after this book is completed. 

Our intention is to first publish 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites' under our TNP banner.  But we won't stop there. We will present the story, along with data from the book's first year of release (2016), to a leading children's publisher, one that already has the distribution channels to bring Kaia to a much larger readership. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

HELP AUTHOR LARRY BRATT GET COPIES OF HIS CHILDREN'S BOOK INTO THE HANDS OF INCARCERATED PARENTS SO THAT THEY CAN READ IT TO THEIR CHILDREN DURING MONTHLY VISITS! WE'RE SIGNING UP PRISONS NOW. NOMINATE THE PRISON OF YOUR CHOICE! BACK THE PROJECT AT ANY LEVEL AND SEND US A MESSAGE!! THIS ACTIVITY BETWEEN PARENT AND CHILD CAN HELP EASE THE TRAUMA OF SEPARATION WHILE THEIR PARENT IS IN PRISON.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

THE INMATE WHO WROTE 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites'...

AUTHOR LARRY BRATT, now 62, is no stranger to correctional institutions. He's been serving time for involvement in a double homicide since 1981 and has been in the real Jessup Penitentiary since 2001. Larry has changed. He is no longer the man who, at a much younger age, committed a serious felony. Larry has pulled together the support and insights of his fellow inmates to launch and drive a hospice program for terminally ill prisoners, a children's book program that provides picture books to inmates with kids, and a gang intervention program that strategizes ways to encourage gangs to redirect their hunger for power into powerful actions for positive change in the communities where they live. Larry has won numerous awards and certificates of commendation. More than 350 of his articles and Op-Ed pieces, many addressing the issue of prison reform, have been published in major market newspapers likeTHE WASHINGTON POST and THE BALTIMORE SUN.


[Link: Endorsements for Larry and His Life-Changing Work]

[Former Warden Gregg L. Hershberger, now the Secretary for Public Safety for the State of Maryland, endorses Larry Bratt's many accomplishments.]

BALTIMORE SUN BREAKS THE STORY ON LARRY BRATT'S CHILDREN'S BOOK

Among the programs he has helped inspire and initiate are:

'READING UNITES FAMILIES'-- a reading program that allows incarcerated fathers and mothers to read with their children;

'EXTRA LEGALESE GROUP'-- awarded a Certificate of Recognition by the State of Maryland Attorney General, this in-prison group develops proven strategies for gang violence intervention within the community outside the prison; and

'HOSPICE BEHIND THE WALLS'-- one of the first programs of its kind, this hospice  proactively addresses and helps meet the physical, emotional, and spiritual needs of inmates with terminal illnesses.



WHO WE ARE:

Too Nuts Productions (TNP) is an online collaboration of writers, editors, producers, sound designers, composers, and illustrators spanning six cities across the U.S.  We also have a troupe of in-house voiceover actors who bring many of our stories to life. And we are represented by one of the most respected licensing agents in the industry.

The TNP team develops literary content for application to a variety of print, audio, and digital platforms. One of our projects, 'The Salivating Salamander,' captured The Pacificus Foundation Award in the Children's Literature category.  As you read this, the TNP collaboration has projects in review at three of the largest children's entertainment distributors and third-party content developers in the industry. Most of our projects are generated from our in-house production team, however, we do consider a handful of intriguing, creative, and spirit-enriching projects from outside the company.  Kaia and the Birthday Kites is one of those projects.

www.toonutsproductions.com


WHY WE DECIDED TO SIGN THE PROJECT AND TO WORK WITH AN INMATE-TURNED-AUTHOR...

Larry’s story, which he started in 2006, and which was only 18 pages at the outset of his venture into publishing, was rejected by more than 30 publishers. That's when he came across our company. About this time, TNP was moving offices. We discovered the nondescript 10x14 clasp envelop stamped "Inmate Mail," which had been placed in a box for unsolicited manuscripts the year before. We opened it and began to read. The note inside this envelope almost moved us to tears. Within, Larry had enclosed a speech he had given back in 2001, when he already had spent more than 19 years behind bars for homicide. The speech, titled, Think Tank Realities, opened with this paragraph: The Roman philosopher Lucretius said, “The moment a man decides to change is the exact moment of that man’s death.” Inside this room and outside this building are many men who long ago decided to change not only their behavior but also their character. For those of us who have changed from criminal to responsible and caring human beings, we have been transformed just as the caterpillar crawling in dirt is transformed into a butterfly capable of flying with a celestial beauty.

When 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites' is published under the Too Nuts Productions banner, TNP will own the rights to the story but Larry, the author, will receive 60% of the proceeds from future sales. He will use his revenues to fund his prison causes. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PLEASE ENJOY THE  VARIOUS GIFTS WE WILL PROVIDE YOU, AT RESPECTIVE LEVELS OF SUPPORT, FOR GRACIOUSLY BACKING THE PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF LARRY'S CHILDREN'S BOOK:


      'Kaia and the Birthday Kites'

 

Sticks and Sheets Level (Your support of $10) - Help build Kaia's dream by contributing at this level and we'll add your name to the Kaia and the Birthday Kites webpage!

///////////////////

String and Tail Level  (Your support of $25) - Help Kaia build her kite and you'll get your very own copy of the book!

 /////////////////// 

 

Launch Level (Your support of $50) - Help Kaia set her kite aloft and we'll send you a copy of the book and a copy of an illustration from the book, drawn by the  talented Christopher Hunter who is a father and inmate at Jessup Correctional Institute!

 //////////////////// 

 

Take Flight Level (Your support of $100) - Help Kaia and her dad, Rashid, reach the sky, and you'll receive an autographed copy of the book signed by author and inmate, Larry Bratt. We will also include your name or the name of a friend (give it as a gift) in the Acknowledgements!

 /////////////////// 

Touch the Clouds Level (Your support of $500) -- Help Kaia and her dad keep their kites in the air, and we'll send you a signed copy of the book. We will also send an original, signed illustration from the book by the talented Christopher Hunter who is a father and inmate at Jessup Correctional Institute. You can also include your name or the name of a friend in the Acknowledgements!

 ///////////////////

 

Soar Forever Level (Your support of $1,000) - When you contribute at this level, you'll receive a signed copy of the book, autographed by Larry Bratt, and a special web address where you will discover the outline of a bowtie-shaped kite (one of multiple kite stabilizing pieces). There, you will be instructed to type your name, along with a short message, inside the bowtie outline.  Then, on March 25, 2016 (Kaia's and her dad's birthday) in a special event taken right from the storyline of 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites,' inmates at Jessup Correctional Institute, under the direction of Larry Bratt, will affix your bowtie drogue to the tail of two kites and, before a crowd of eager onlookers including reporters and children of inmates, will launch both kites into the sky.  You will make history. We will also include your name or a name of a friend in the Acknowledgements.

We will also include your name or the name of a friend in the Acknowledgements!

WHERE WE ARE NOW:

The story is currently in second round editorial. It will undergo a minimum of three editorial passes: Draft A w/ Edits, Draft B w/ Edits, and Draft C w/ Edits. TNP is currently exploring both foreign and domestic printing sources. We would like to produce the project entirely in the U.S.  Budgetary considerations may render this option futile.  But we are exploring the option.

At $29,000, you might at first conclude that "Hey, that's a lot of money only to produce a children's book, isn't it?" In fact, when you factor in illustration, book design, editorial and manufacturing costs, as well as support services like legal (intellectual property protection / contracts) and accounting (to make sure we stay on budget), you'd be impressed at how quickly you can burn through the production budget. We are not going to allow that to happen. Hence why we've contracted the accounting firm of 'Dawn Catherine Taxes & Accounting' (DawnCatherine.com). Dawn Catherine, E.A., an 'Enrolled Agent,' sits on the boards of 10 banks and is one of the most respected accountants in Northern California. Production........$7,500

story_txt:
Kaia and the Birthday Kites is a fictional story of one determined young girl's mission to spend her birthday with the man she admires most, and for her dad to spend his birthday with the daughter he loves.  Dad is an inmate at Jessup, a maximum security prison in the suburbs of Baltimore.

Left: 'Kaia'  (Illustration by Christopher Hunter.) 
Approximately 2.7 million children under the age of 18 have a parent in state or federal
prison according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, and the
number keeps growing. These
children have a higher risk for drugs and alcohol abuse, antisocial behavior,
dropping out of school or declining in schoolwork, as well as aggression,
disruptive behaviors, and depression when compared to other children. These factors make it more likely that the children will enter the prison system
when they are adults. Kaia and the
Birthday Kites author, Larry Bratt, is an inmate at Jessup and sees these
statistics become reality all too often. This book is
positioned to give hope to the children of the nation's incarcerated, and
to encourage them to follow a different path than their incarcerated parents. We also hope that this book can start a dialogue within our nation, and throughout the world, about these often hidden victims of incarceration. 


THE STORY:
Kaia is about to turn 13. 
Her birthday is on March 25th.  So is her dad's. Like any young girl about to celebrate a big day, she wants to celebrate it with the one she loves most. Only one problem. She'll have to get past the guards.  And the watchtower.  And the electric fence.  And the angry dogs tethered to leather straps.  Because Kaia wants to deliver dad a present, the perfect gift for dad and daughter to share. And the ultimate symbol of freedom: two kites. On father and daughter's birthday, Kaia wants to fly those kites with dad...in the prison yard.
[Read excerpts HERE.]
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

HOW CAN I HELP?
Author Larry Bratt has turned around his life and, in the main, has turned around the lives of many others inside and outside the walls of Jessup.  That's why we're asking you to help us get him published. We want to spread Larry's (and Kaia's) message of perseverance and why it's important to do what's right even if your life didn't start out that way.
We need your help by donating funds and spreading the word about this book. Larry needs your help, too.  After covering production costs, Larry intends to take his portion of sales revenue from 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites' and reinvest in the young and the old. Larry will commit a portion of his proceeds to the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland's 'Camp Amazing Grace' for the children of incarcerated dads and moms so that they can attend summer camp. He will also invest his proceeds into the Prison Hospice program to bring comfort to and improve palliative care for inmates who are terminally ill. Your donation will continue to give long after this book is completed. 
Our intention is to first publish 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites' under our TNP banner.  But we won't stop there. We will present the story, along with data from the book's first year of release (2016), to a leading children's publisher, one that already has the distribution channels to bring Kaia to a much larger readership. 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
HELP AUTHOR LARRY BRATT GET COPIES OF HIS CHILDREN'S BOOK INTO THE HANDS OF INCARCERATED PARENTS SO THAT THEY CAN READ IT TO THEIR CHILDREN DURING MONTHLY VISITS! WE'RE SIGNING UP PRISONS NOW. NOMINATE THE PRISON OF YOUR CHOICE! BACK THE PROJECT AT ANY LEVEL AND SEND US A MESSAGE!! THIS ACTIVITY BETWEEN PARENT AND CHILD CAN HELP EASE THE TRAUMA OF SEPARATION WHILE THEIR PARENT IS IN PRISON.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


THE INMATE WHO WROTE 'Kaia and the Birthday
Kites'...
AUTHOR LARRY BRATT, now 62, is no stranger to correctional
institutions. He's been serving time for involvement in a double
homicide since 1981 and has been in the real Jessup Penitentiary since
2001. Larry has changed. He is no longer the man who, at a much younger age,
committed a serious felony. Larry has pulled together the
support and insights of his fellow inmates to launch and drive a
hospice program for terminally ill prisoners, a children's book program that
provides picture books to inmates with kids, and a gang intervention program
that strategizes ways to encourage gangs to redirect their hunger for
power into powerful actions for positive change in the communities
where they live. Larry has won numerous awards and certificates of
commendation. More than 350 of his
articles and Op-Ed pieces, many addressing the issue of prison
reform, have been published in major market newspapers likeTHE WASHINGTON POST and THE BALTIMORE SUN.

[Link: Endorsements for Larry and His Life-Changing Work]
[Former Warden Gregg L. Hershberger, now the Secretary for Public Safety for the State of Maryland, endorses Larry Bratt's many accomplishments.]

BALTIMORE SUN BREAKS THE STORY ON LARRY BRATT'S CHILDREN'S BOOK
Among the programs he has helped inspire and initiate are:
'READING UNITES FAMILIES'-- a reading program that allows incarcerated fathers and
mothers to read with their children;
'EXTRA LEGALESE GROUP'-- awarded a Certificate of Recognition by the State of Maryland
Attorney General, this in-prison group develops proven strategies for gang
violence intervention within the community outside the prison; and
'HOSPICE BEHIND THE
WALLS'-- one of the first programs of its kind, this hospice 
proactively addresses and helps meet the physical, emotional, and spiritual
needs of inmates with terminal illnesses.











WHO WE ARE:
Too Nuts Productions (TNP) is
an online collaboration of writers, editors, producers, sound designers,
composers, and illustrators spanning six cities across the U.S.  We also
have a troupe of in-house voiceover actors who bring many of our stories to
life. And we are represented by one of the most respected licensing agents in
the industry.
The TNP team develops literary content for application to a
variety of print, audio, and digital platforms. One of our projects, 'The
Salivating Salamander,' captured The Pacificus Foundation Award in the
Children's Literature category.  As you read this, the TNP collaboration
has projects in review at three of the largest children's entertainment
distributors and third-party content developers in the industry. Most of our
projects are generated from our in-house production team, however, we do
consider a handful of intriguing, creative, and spirit-enriching projects from
outside the company.  Kaia and the Birthday Kites is one of those
projects. 
www.toonutsproductions.com


WHY WE DECIDED TO SIGN
THE PROJECT AND TO WORK WITH AN INMATE-TURNED-AUTHOR...
Larry’s story, which he started in 2006, and which was only
18 pages at the outset of his venture into publishing, was rejected by more
than 30 publishers. That's when he came across our company. About this
time, TNP was moving offices. We discovered the nondescript 10x14 clasp
envelop stamped "Inmate Mail," which had been placed in a box for
unsolicited manuscripts the year before. We opened it and began to read. The note inside this envelope almost moved us to
tears. Within, Larry had enclosed a speech he had given back in 2001, when he
already had spent more than 19 years behind bars for homicide. The speech,
titled, Think
Tank Realities, opened with this
paragraph: The Roman philosopher Lucretius said, “The moment a man decides to
change is the exact moment of that man’s death.” Inside this room and outside
this building are many men who long ago decided to change not only their
behavior but also their character. For those of us who have changed from
criminal to responsible and caring human beings, we have been transformed just
as the caterpillar crawling in dirt is transformed into a butterfly capable of
flying with a celestial beauty.
When 'Kaia and the Birthday Kites' is published under the Too
Nuts Productions banner, TNP will own the rights to the story but Larry, the
author, will receive 60% of the proceeds from future sales. He will use his
revenues to fund his prison causes.

story:
FINAL UPDATE: THANK YOU

EVERYONE!

While we came just a few hundred dollars short of our goal, "Goodnight Loon" is a success. Nearly 100 people supported us, getting themselves a truly unique book and in the process raising $711 for the Audubon Center of the North Woods and 48 (!) books for the Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota's Wee Read, a program that provides books to children staying in the hospital's NICU, ICC or SCN. For those waiting for books (and books with extras), we expect to have them delivered to you by Dec 13.

Meanwhile, for those interested in meeting us or in more books, the authors will be part of a small "Goodnight Loon" event at Garrison Keillor's Common Good Books in St. Paul, MN on Dec. 21 at 2:00 pm. For more information or to ask us anything, please email info@goodnightloon.com.

Thank you!

UPDATE 1: MONDAY WEE READ

PROGRAM BOOK MATCH!

One support level allows you to buy a copy and donate a copy of "Goodnight Loon" to the Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota's Wee Reads, a program that provides books to children staying in the hospital's NICU, ICC or SCN. We will now MATCH every Ole and Lena Level, Wee Read book donation made, one for one. That means, if 30 books are donated to Wee Read, we will match and donate ANOTHER 30 books!

UPDATE 2: "GOODNIGHT LOON" IS

HAPPENING NO MATTER WHAT

As we move into the last hours of funding, we want to thank everyone for their valuable support. As "Goodnight Loon" was flexibly funded, we will be producing and sending everyone their books even if we do not meet our target. Our current target date to deliver the book to you is December 13. Meanwhile, to get a fun idea of what you get with the book, watch the video above of one Minnesota grandfather reading "Goodnight Loon."


'GOODNIGHT LOON' THE BOOK

AT ITS SIMPLEST, this book is "Goodnight Moon" for the northwoods.

By "northwoods" we mean both the glorious Boundary Waters Canoe Area as well as all of the canoeing, camping, fishing and hunting areas in the American mid-north (or Canadian south). There are loons in Wisconsin too! And in Maine, so we've been told.

We read "Goodnight Moon" to our kids all time and have come to love the nuance and detail brought out by illustrator Clement Hurd. The change in the moon's trajectory, the advancement of the clock, the little mouse's explorations and the dying fire. We've worked hard to capture the original book's lyrical charm and detail while at the same time making it local from start to finish, top to bottom. The book features walleyes, pies, rod, fish, a hotdish, ticks, food on sticks, an old voyageur, a hungry raccoon, a curious loon and much more.

"Goodnight Loon" will be a full board book, made of stout, durable cardboard pages. Throw it against the wall, run over it with a bicycle, spill ice cream on the cover... this book will be printed to endure. (Look at the prototypes above; so pretty!)

Even better, a portion of each sale will benefit northwoods wildlife and habitats.

With the help of a few generous donors and your support, we will be able to minimize the funding target to make "Goodnight Loon" possible while at the same time offering the books at the low price of $10... including shipping.

YOU GIVE A BOOK TO 'WEE READS' / WE GIVE 25% TO THE AUDUBON CENTER OF THE NORTH WOODS

ONE OF OUR REWARDS allows you to buy a copy and donate a copy of "Goodnight Loon" to the Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota's Wee Reads, a program that provides books to children staying in the hospital's NICU, ICC or SCN.

We will also be donating 25 percent of all profits from the "Goodnight Loon" launch to the Audubon Center of the North Woods. On Grindstone Lake, the Audubon Center operates a 535-acre sanctuary for local animals, hardwood forests, wetlands and prairies and, of course, loons. The center also operates a wildlife rehab facility and an environmental learning center that is visited by thousands of area K to 12 students every year. 

FUN, LOCAL REWARDS INCLUDING GARRISON KEILLOR AND DULUTH PACK

IN ADDITION TO THE BOOK, we have a collection of fun, odd and local rewards. Make your copy of "Goodnight Loon" interactive with a plush loon. Other support levels include a copy of the excellent crop art biography "Seed Queen," a plush walleye, and a vintage "Man of Action" Jesse Ventura special "Governor of Minnesota edition" action figure. Or, have the book's creators write and illustrate a letter to the Minnesota mayor of your choice complaining about the potholes on your street.

As its iconic bag makes an appearence in the book, Minnesota's own Duluth Pack has generously donated a few of its durable products to help make the book possible. There is either the official miniature #3 Duluth Pack (perfect for dolls or the Christmas tree) or several full size classic #51 Utility Canoe Packs. All, of course, include the book.

There is the buy one, give one reward for the Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota's Wee Reads program which is really two rewards. And last but not least, we are lucky enough to be offering a limited number of opportunities to have Garrison Keillor personalize a copy of the book for a child you know.

FAQs

Q: I'm not Minnesotan. Can I still get this book?
A: Yes! Everyone can order and enjoy "Goodnight Loon" except for Erik Eklund and he knows why. (Keep in mind that shipping to Canada and internationally is $12 extra.)

Q: Is there an e-book?
A: At the moment we are not offering an e-book version.

Q: Why not?
A: It's so nice. You should be playing outside.

Q: Why not?
A: Look at all that grass. Why don't you play outside. 

Q: Will "Goodnight Loon" be available elsewhere?
A: Yes. We plan to get "Goodnight Loon" in as many local bookstores as possible, from Common Good Books in St. Paul to Drury Lane Books in Grand Marais to the Duluth Pack store in, of course, Duluth.

Q: I'm a librarian. Can I get a copy for our library?
A: Please email us! info@goodnightloon.com.)

Q: Will there be a book launch party in Minnesota?
A: Yes! To receive more info on this, email info@goodnightloon.com.

Q: I'm a member of the media. How do I contact you?
A: Email us! info@goodnightloon.com.

Q: Is any portion of of my payment tax deductible?
A: Nope.

Q: Where is Minnesota's best Paul Bunyan statue?
A: Trick question! Minnesota's best Paul Bunyan statue is actually Pierre the pantsless voyageur in Two Harbors. This is closed to argument.

ABOUT THE AUTHORS

BROTHERS, we were born and raised on one of those Midwest family dairy farms that hardly exist anymore. We grew up in profound sincerity, milking cows and listening to Garrison Keillor and longing for the day when we could leave. And we did. Then something changed. We don't milk cows anymore and when we listen to Garrison Keillor it's a little less sincerely. But we've come to value regional personality, especially what it means to be from a place. We think this book is an excellent characterization of our life philosophy: Copy other ideas.

Wait, no.

We mean that everyone should value connecting with others on a single, shared level while at the same time staying proudly particular in ways those others might not understand.   

Abe Sauer lives in Minnesota and Wisconsin and is the author of, in addition to other things, the book of humor "How to be: NORTH DAKOTA. A Guide to the Plains." He is the father of two daughters with another on the way.

Nathaniel Davauer lives in Milwaukee where he is a professional photographer, illustrator and artist. He has three daughters.

RISKS

HAVE YOU READ anything about the publishing industry lately? In the time it takes to complete this project, it's a genuine possibility that the eyeballs of American children will have evolved to no longer recognize things printed on paper. And we can't fight science.

Meanwhile, as with all such projects, supply chains can encounter setbacks. Board book printing is much more complex than conventional book production. Transportation is a potential hiccup; trucks break down or can be destroyed by a sharknado. Or, in a northwoods case, a moosenado. Finally, this is Minnesota, so even if we were in the car driving your book to you at this very moment, we would caution you not to get your hopes up. Who knows, maybe we'll remember we left the oven on and turn around to go back and check.

We are 90% sure we will meet our pre-Christmas delivery target. But we will immediately communicate any unexpected delays. We will also be reloading Paul Huttner's MPR Updraft blog on an hourly basis for moosenado alerts.

RESPECT

FINALLY, we want to express our profound respect and appreciation to Margaret Wise Brown and Clement Hurd, the original author/illustrator team of "Goodnight Moon." It's a crime if you come to own our parody and not the original.

You should be playing outside. Q: Why not? A: Look at all that grass. Why don't you play outside.  Q: Will "Goodnight Loon" be available elsewhere?A: Yes. We plan to get "Goodnight Loon" in as many local bookstores as possible, from Common Good Books in St. Paul to Drury Lane Books in Grand Marais to the Duluth Pack store in, of course, Duluth. Q: I'm a librarian. Can I get a copy for our library?A: Please email us! info@goodnightloon.com.)Q: Will there be a book launch party in Minnesota?A: Yes! To receive more info on this, email info@goodnightloon.com.Q: I'm a member of the media. How do I contact you?A: Email us! info@goodnightloon.com. Q: Is any portion of of my payment tax deductible? A: Nope. Q: Where is Minnesota's best Paul Bunyan statue? A: Trick question! Minnesota's best Paul Bunyan statue is actually Pierre the pantsless voyageur in Two Harbors. This is closed to argument. ABOUT THE AUTHORS 
BROTHERS, we were born and raised on one of those Midwest family dairy farms that hardly exist anymore. We grew up in profound sincerity, milking cows and listening to Garrison Keillor and longing for the day when we could leave. And we did. Then something changed. We don't milk cows anymore and when we listen to Garrison Keillor it's a little less sincerely. But we've come to value regional personality, especially what it means to be from a place. We think this book is an excellent characterization of our life philosophy: Copy other ideas. Wait, no. We mean that everyone should value connecting with others on a single, shared level while at the same time staying proudly particular in ways those others might not understand.   Abe Sauer lives in Minnesota and Wisconsin and is the author of, in addition to other things, the book of humor "How to be: NORTH DAKOTA. A Guide to the Plains." He is the father of two daughters with another on the way. Nathaniel Davauer lives in Milwaukee where he is a professional photographer, illustrator and artist. He has three daughters. 
RISKS HAVE YOU READ anything about the publishing industry 
lately? In the time it takes to complete this project, it's a genuine 
possibility that the eyeballs of American children will have evolved to no longer
 recognize things printed on paper. And we can't fight science. Meanwhile,
 as with all such projects, supply chains can encounter setbacks. Board 
book printing is much more complex than conventional book production. 
Transportation is a potential hiccup; trucks break down or can be 
destroyed by a sharknado. Or, in a northwoods case, a moosenado. 
Finally, this is Minnesota, so even if we were in the car driving your 
book to you at this very moment, we would caution you not to get your 
hopes up. Who knows, maybe we'll remember we left the oven on and turn 
around to go back and check. We are 90% sure we will meet our pre-Christmas 
delivery target. But we will immediately 
communicate any unexpected delays. We will also be reloading Paul Huttner's MPR Updraft blog on an hourly basis for moosenado alerts. 
RESPECTFINALLY, we want to express our profound respect and appreciation to Margaret Wise Brown and Clement Hurd, the original 
author/illustrator team of "Goodnight Moon." It's a crime if you come to
 own our parody and not the original.

story:
"It is now highly feasible to take care of everybody on Earth at a higher standard of living than any have ever known. It no longer has to be you or me. Selfishness is unnecessary. War is obsolete. It is a mater of converting the high technology from weaponry to livingry.”


"Humanity is taking its final examination.  We have come to an extraordinary moment when it doesn't have to be you or me.  There is enough for all.  We need not operate competitively any longer.  If we succeed, it will be because of youth, truth and love."

- Dr. R. Buckminster Fuller


This is it. We’re in what Bucky Fuller labeled “humanity’s final examination,” and we must each answer the cosmic question he often posed,

“Are humans a worthwhile to Universe experiment?”

The purpose of this project is to help us answer “yes” and create a sustainable, peaceful, abundant life for all people and life on the fragile planet Bucky called Spaceship Earth.

I’m asking you to help us fund this very important piece of the global success puzzle.I’m asking you to financially support my new book "A Fuller View so that it can reach the most people in the shortest amount of time because time is critical to our survival and success as a species.  My first Bucky Fuller book Buckminster Fuller's Universe has made a difference to thousands of people, but we now need to make Bucky's wisdom and solutions even more available.

CLICK HERE FOR A SHORT BUCKY FULLER VIDEO BIO

CLICK HERE TO WATCH A 1974 VIDEO OF BUCKY SHARING SOME IMPORTANT IDEAS


US Pavilion at the 1976 Montreal World's Fair.
This SkyBreak Geodesic Dome designed by Bucky Fuller
was the top attraction at the Fair and
became known as his Taj Majal Masterpiece.


This initiative is designed to be the spark that brings Fuller and his wisdom back into the public spotlight so that we can all live lives filled with peace, joy and love. It is not some pie-in-the-sky vision. The book A Fuller View and the initiatives surrounding it will educate people to the fact that there is enough to support all life and that war and selfishness are now obsolete.

This was not something that could have been known or experienced by our parents or grandparents. This is a new phenomenon, and we have to accept our responsibility as stewards of Spaceship Earth and begin taking action on behalf of all sentient beings.



“The most important thing about Spaceship Earth - an instruction book didn't come with it.”  - Bucky Fuller


We’re all in this together, and Fuller was one of the first people to recognize our plight.  He also realized that we humans don’t have a clue as to how to operate our tiny,  fragile Spaceship Earth, and he wrote the classic “Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth” to help people more fully appreciate what is needed to create a sustainable environment that supports all life on Earth.

This project returns Fuller’s vision of  “A World That Works for Everyone” and the simple solutions he posed into the public spotlight.   This is extremely important as we teeter on the brink of destroying much of the life on Earth as well as the sustainability of our environment.



“There is something patently insane about all the typewriters sleeping with all the beautiful plumbing in the beautiful office buildings -- and all the people sleeping in the slums.” - Bucky Fuller



Long before most of us woke up to the fact that we’re living in a crazy culture where there are plenty of resources to house machinery and to create more and more weaponry, Bucky was championing the importance of “livingry” - things that support life.  Today, this is an even more critical distinction to make, and this project will educate people on resource allocation and how we can be a species that successfully stewards our planet for the benefit of all.

I have studied, written and spoken about Bucky’s vision since 1979, and I find it to hold the best solution to all humankind’s problems.  I know it to be useful in my life and the lives of many others.  Now is the critical moment when we need this vision of a positive, sustainable future more than ever, and your financial contribution will help make Bucky’s inspirational perspective more known and visible.

The first major tool in this work is my new Bucky Fuller book A Fuller View - Exploring Bucky Fuller's Vision of Hope & Abundance for All to be published by Divine Arts Media in March 2012.  In addition to dozens of essential Bucky Fuller quotes and my writing, the book contains commentaries by luminaries including

·    Gary Zukav - Author - Seat of the Soul - Spiritual Partnership -The Dancing Wu Li Masters
·    John Robbins - Author - Diet for a New America - The New Good Life
·    Dr. Jean Houston - Author - Mind Games & A Mythic Life & The Search for the Beloved
·    Dr. Joel Levey - co-author "Wisdom at Work" & "Living in Balance"
·    Michelle Levey - co-author "Wisdom at Work" & "Living in Balance"
·    Barbara Marx Hubbard - Founder of the Foundation for Conscious Evolution
·    Dr. Rick Ingrasci - Co-founder of Interface, American Holistic Medical Association, Hollyhock
·    Dr. Hazel Henderson - Founder of Ethical Markets Media
·    Ocean Robbins - Founder of YES!
·    Peter Meisen - Founder of the Global Energy Network Institute (GENI)
·    Ann Medlock - Founder & Director of The Giraffe Project
·    David Spangler - Author of Blessing: The Art and the Practice & Coming Home
·    Bobbi DePorter - Founder and CEO of SuperCamp
·    Justine Toms - Co-Founder and Director of New Dimensions Radio
·    Kevin Todeschi - Executive Director and CEO of Edgar Cayce’s A.R.E.
·    Ross Quinn - Facilitator Lifestream; Author - The Love Based Leader
·    Jamal Rahman - Muslim Sufi Minister, Cominister Interfaith Community Church
·    Medard Gable - CEO, Big Picture Small World
·    Michael Wiese - Filmmaker, Author - The Independent Film & Videomaker's Guide


Bucky's 1933 Dymaxion Vehicle.
3 prototypes built. Seated 11, got 30 plus miles per gallon
top speed 120 plus mph. Could easily be parked in a space
just 3 inches longer than the vehicle itself. The car we need
today produced 1933.


A Fuller View is compact guide outlining how we can quickly create a global “you and me” society of cooperation and peace to replace our “you or me” competitive culture of war and domination.  It also plots a course for readers to discover their true gifts and passions and freely contribute them to others.

My first Bucky book Buckminster Fuller’s Universe provides a more comprehensive yet very readable examination of Fuller, his life and wisdom.  It was written in response to people seeking an easy to understand doorway to Bucky.


Here’s what some people said about Buckminster Fuller’s Universe:

"Buckminster Fuller was a great man.  Everybody concerned about the planet should read this book.  It fully illustrates that a great man walked among us."
    Larry King

"Buckminster Fuller's genius and vision are more relevant than ever before.  Bucky's whole systems view is crucial to the future of humanity and the planet, and Steven Sieden brings his wisdom to life in Buckminster Fuller's Universe. Anyone concerned about the future needs to be aware of what Bucky discovered during his lifetime and this book provides a thorough exposition of Bucky's principles and philosophy."
    Michael Toms
    Co-founder & CEO, New Dimensions Radio
    
"Buckminster Fuller's Universe is a vivid, personal and revealing work which brings Fuller home to us all.  The Design Science Revolution which he called for is now at its time of greatest social relevance.  Bucky's legacy is needed now.  This book is a real contribution to our collective purpose of a social agenda for the next century."
    Barbara Marx Hubbard
    Author, Futurist

"To have known Bucky and witnessed his disciplined dedication to humanity through engineering was an inspirational treat in my life.  Steven Sieden's interpretations of Fuller's creative genius should greatly enhance public acknowledgement of the intellectual wisdom of this diminutive giant.  I predict Bucky's ideas will permeate new architectural opportunities in the coming age of space."
    Dr. Buzz Aldrin
    Author, speaker and former astronaut

"Buckminster Fuller's Universe is a very necessary and useful book.  It relates the development of Fuller's ideas, which could initiate intelligent global action without politics, to the events of his life.  The book is not written in Fuller's language.  It is written in yours.  You will understand it."
    John Cage

"In Buckminster Fuller's Universe, Steven Sieden provides a lucid, insightful, and significant exploration of the man behind the public figure.  Buckminster Fuller, designer/philosopher extraordinary, was one of the first to take a comprehensive look at using the world's resources efficiently for the benefit of all humanity.  Now Sieden probes beyond Fuller's famous inventions to offer a unique psychological perspective on the roots of his successes and failures."
    Amory B. Lovins
    Author, speaker & Director of Research, Rocky Mountain Institute

If you help us by contributing on this site, A Fuller View will go well beyond Buckminster Fuller’s Universe in making Fuller and his wisdom a more prominent force for positive transformation and change.



Who is Bucky Fuller, and why is he important now?
    
In 1927 Bucky Fuller was an alcoholic contemplating suicide.  Instead of ending his life, he turned it into a personal experiment to determine and document what one individual could accomplish that could not be achieved by any government, corporation, religion or other institution no matter how rich or powerful.  Bucky’s experiment lasted for 56 years until his death in 1983.  During that period he was recognized as an inventor, futurist, educator, philosopher architect and global visionary.  

Bucky Fuller was often said to be “busy as a beaver.” This unique
cover from a 1976 program
illustrates that characteristic.
He also generated an income of more than one million dollars per year during the early 1950s while remaining true to his commitment to never work for a living.  He was known as "Grandfather of the Universe," a title which acknowledges the magnitude of his wisdom and contribution.

Conducting an experiment without follow-up and analysis leaves an enormous void.  The true value of Fuller's experiment cannot be manifest until others learn from it and apply his findings to their lives.

Throughout his life, Fuller constantly analyzed his actions to determine what worked well and what was less than useful.  I have now explored and interpreted the entirety of Fuller's life and work so that I can provide deeper insights into his well-documented experiment using books, online recordings and live speeches.

Please join me in this most important project.  Our planet and our species are depending on us to educate and inspire people to take action.


“We are on a spaceship; a beautiful one. It took billions of years to develop. We're not going to get another. Now, how do we make this spaceship work?”  - Bucky Fuller



Excerpted from A Fuller View Guest Commentaries

By Gary Zukav
Bucky said, "Love is metaphysical gravity." I agree. What else could it be? Without gravity you would float like an astronaut in a spacecraft. Up and down would mean nothing to you. … Without love the same thing happens. Every experience of anger, jealousy, resentment, and fear sends you spinning out of control.

By John Robbins
The innocence of young people is not a fault to be corrected, nor an ignorance to be educated, but a strength to be celebrated. Sometimes it takes courage to be innocent. Sometimes the truly daring thing to do is to be naive. Bucky's words remind me that my cynicism can be a trap, that my suspiciousness and defensiveness and know-it-all-ness can blind me, can keep me from awe, wonder and amazement.

Of course it is our task to guide our children so that they may live with respect for themselves and respect for others. But Bucky reminds us that our function is never to seek to impose our limited and limiting beliefs upon them, but rather to help them to develop so they may give the gifts they are here to give, and to receive the gifts that others have for them, as well.

My son, Ocean Robbins, has been a superb teacher for me in this respect. He builds on all that I've accomplished. He and I are stunningly compatible in our values and visions. But he goes places I could never go.

By Michael Wiese
I had the extreme good fortune to know Bucky, to see him in action, and try to put his teachings into practice. He influenced and changed the direction of my life.

1970 - I am in my early twenties, living in Tokyo, when someone sends me Stewart Brand's The Whole Earth Catalog. I order all of Bucky's books and read them in my tiny tatami room. In a world convinced that scarcity is the norm, Bucky is the first person I've ever heard who is certain the world holds abundance and by employing design science we can raise the standard of living for everyone. Sitting in a temple in Kyoto, it occurs to me that Bucky may have taken the vow of the bodhisattva.

1972 - I am visiting my folks in Champaign Illinois. I've been invited to a luncheon lecture at my mother's Art Club. As the red Jello is being passed around, the din of silverware on china is hushed by a loud noise as the speaker bangs his shoe on the podium. It is Buckminster Fuller. "It's 5 minutes to midnight!" "This is humanity's final exam!" Shocked silence. Inwardly, I cheer, "Go Bucky Go!" Afterwards, I hurry up to meet the great man.

By David Spangler
Like many geniuses, Bucky Fuller has left us an extensive and wonderful treasure of quotable statements. Picking one is like being asked to choose one's favorite food amongst a buffet of culinary delights where each item has its own unique flavor and attraction. It's a task both difficult and enjoyable at the same time.

By Kevin J. Todeschi
As a longtime resource on the Edgar Cayce information, I would have to say that my favorite Bucky quote is the one-line in which he states, "I am a passenger on the spaceship Earth." Although it can certainly be seen by some as a simple statement, for me it embodies a rich array of possibilities and truths about the nature of humankind and the interconnectedness of the entire human family.


Here’s how we’re planning to use your generous contributions to create Bucky's vision of "a world that works for everyone":

Manuscript Editing $3,200
Creation and Publicizing Website(s) & Blog(s) $3,500
Solicitation of Additional Guest Commentators $1,200
Marketing & Promotion $2,500
Speaking at Events $2,900
Creation of Video(s) - Promotional & Educational $2,800
Social Networking $1,900
